page.title: 02INTRODUCTION
page.content: This rural area has been studied by the older children of Pittington Junior,Mixed and Infant School. It was not mentioned in the original{Domesday {Book}but nearby areas received some comment in the{Boldon Book}in 1183. A century ago this district was an active part of the Durham Coal-field, but now the land is for either agricultural or residential use. The school's catchment area includes the three villages of Low Pittington, High Pittington and Littletown. The villages of Pittington lie on the lower slopes of a hill, appropriately called Pittington Hill, and one of the "Beacon" hills of old. This notable hill is about four miles South-East of Durham, and together with the Church of St. Laurence at Hallgarth, has provided the basis for the children's investigations.
